tweets.text: Very excited to announce that I'm joining The Free Press as a contributing writer! @TheFP @bariweiss https://t.co/c7GQYZGMux

If you like freedom of the press -the real kind, not the kind mediated by careerists, partisans, weaklings and cowards - check out  @thefp.

All we want is the truth. We'll figure out what to do with it.

@walterkirn @bariweiss @TheFP hope you write about the good, the bad and the ugly no matter which side of the aisle is the subject matter. Please use journalist integrety and fully confirm stories. looking forward to watching your site
@walterkirn @bariweiss @TheFP Unfortunately the press may be free to say whatever they want, but if we the people want the truth, we have to pay a monthly subscription fee of 9.99 a month!
@BariWeiss is the editor, I will follow @TheFP https://t.co/BRTUkClMXr
@BullyMaus @TheFP I assume a Common Sense subscription transfers across?
@TheFP @bariweiss https - it's a thing, but you don't seem to have it
Proud to be a contributor https://t.co/bolPXsQj3Y https://t.co/z20UrSlnWv

urls.title: Common Sense
urls.description: Honest news for sane people brought to you by Bari Weiss. Click to read Common Sense, a Substack publication.

tweets.text:
It's easy to complain about the status quo and much harder to create something new -- congratulations @bariweiss and the crew from @TheFP:
https://t.co/7yyQCHrpVb
I'm thrilled to be part of the fantastic team at The Free Press @TheFP that @bariweiss has built. We so look forward to bringing readers and listeners more great journalism. https://t.co/zkYGimvoe1

Why I joined @thefp: 

I knew I didn’t fit in when Politico let @benshapiro guest write an edition of Playbook. I told a colleague I was stoked because “this helps legitimize us.” They responded that they were taking a mental health day to process ‘Shapirogate.’

We’re living in a golden age of independent journalism and independent thought.

Proud to start writing again at @TheFP. https://t.co/nr5lrJxsG9
Full read of the link is worth it, but I especially liked this line. Good idea to set expectations from the start. This will create a strong foundation for them.
Am following. Also willing to pay. If I am proven wrong over time, at least I tried to have faith in the possibility of journalism again. https://t.co/1mXtAw4NfS
@rupasubramanya @bariweiss @TheFP Rupa is a rockstar journalist! Big loss for the national post, big win for the free press.
Really honored to get to write for @bariweiss in this new institution she is creating 👇👇. Subscribe. Impartial journalism is needed now more than ever. https://t.co/M9grF9vP0A
This is the next step in the evolution from @bariweiss ‘s Common Sense.  Am thrilled to be part of @thefp team and be part of the journey! https://t.co/PRrhbNTo4G
I’m so proud of the team we are building and the journalism we are doing @TheFP. We’re just getting started. https://t.co/4xOEef306D

I'm curious about what role the government played in Twitter's suppression of covid policy discussion. We will see with time, I suppose.
 
Thank you @bariweiss and @elonmusk. Sunshine is the best disinfectant.
2/2

Still trying to process my emotions on learning that @twitter blacklisted me. The thought that will keep me up tonight: censorship of scientific discussion permitted policies like school closures & a generation of children were hurt. 
1/2
@brianstelter @bariweiss @TheFP Is this free press actually, you know, free?

urls.title: Common Sense
urls.description: Honest news for sane people brought to you by Bari Weiss. Click to read Common Sense, a Substack publication.

tweets.text:
27. There is more to come on this story, which was reported by @abigailshrier @shellenbergermd @nelliebowles @isaacgrafstein and the team The Free Press @thefp. 

Keep up with this unfolding story here and at our brand new website: https://t.co/qYaBJzKcZj.

29. We're just getting started on our reporting. Documents cannot tell the whole story here. A big thank you to everyone who has spoken to us so far. If you are a current or former Twitter employee, we'd love to hear from you. Please write to: tips@thefp.com

13. But there existed a level beyond official ticketing, beyond the rank-and-file moderators following the company’s policy on paper. That is the “Site Integrity Policy, Policy Escalation Support,” known as “SIP-PES.”
12. The group that decided whether to limit the reach of certain users was the Strategic Response Team - Global Escalation Team, or SRT-GET. It often handled up to 200 "cases" a day.

11. “We control visibility quite a bit. And we control the amplification of your content quite a bit. And normal people do not know how much we do,” one Twitter engineer told us. Two additional Twitter employees confirmed.
10. All without users’ knowledge.

9. “VF” refers to Twitter’s control over user visibility. It used VF to block searches of individual users; to limit the scope of a particular tweet’s discoverability; to block select users’ posts from ever appearing on the “trending” page; and from inclusion in hashtag searches.
8. “Think about visibility filtering as being a way for us to suppress what people see to different levels. It’s a very powerful tool,” one senior Twitter employee told us.
7. What many people call “shadow banning,” Twitter executives and employees call “Visibility Filtering” or “VF.” Multiple high-level sources confirmed its meaning.

6. Twitter denied that it does such things. In 2018, Twitter's Vijaya Gadde (then Head of Legal Policy and Trust) and Kayvon Beykpour (Head of Product) said: “We do not shadow ban.” They added: “And we certainly don’t shadow ban based on political viewpoints or ideology.”
5. Twitter set the account of conservative activist Charlie Kirk (@charliekirk11) to “Do Not Amplify.” https://t.co/dOyQIVdsW2
4. Or consider the popular right-wing talk show host, Dan Bongino (@dbongino), who at one point was slapped with a “Search Blacklist.” https://t.co/AdOK8xLu9v

3. Take, for example, Stanford’s Dr. Jay Bhattacharya (@DrJBhattacharya) who argued that Covid lockdowns would harm children. Twitter secretly placed him on a “Trends Blacklist,” which prevented his tweets from trending. https://t.co/qTW22Zh691
2. Twitter once had a mission “to give everyone the power to create and share ideas and information instantly, without barriers.” Along the way, barriers nevertheless were erected.

1. A new #TwitterFiles investigation reveals that teams of Twitter employees build blacklists, prevent disfavored tweets from trending, and actively limit the visibility of entire accounts or even trending topics—all in secret, without informing users.

THREAD: THE TWITTER FILES PART TWO. 

TWITTER’S SECRET BLACKLISTS.
